results.title: Planning metrication
results.creator_credit: Stanley Marks, Stephen Cross and New Decade Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Keys to Metrication”.
The success of metrication depends on careful planning to keep companies in step with their suppliers and customers, and to keep company departments in step with one another. How to start and organise the changeover, aspects of phasing, control and costs, staff familiarisation and training; the importance of timing and of using the opportunity for rationalisation which metrication offers to large and small concerns.

results.title: Phasing in metric designs
results.creator_credit: Stanley Marks, Stephen Cross, New Decade Productions and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keys to Metrication”.
The changeover to metric design will normally be gradual and needs careful preparation. Imperial past can be incorporated in a metric environment of vice versa.

results.title: Metric production and inspection
results.creator_credit: Stanley Marks, Stephen Cross, Central Office of Information and New Decade Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keys to Metrication”.
Most imperial machines and cutting tools can be used for the production of metric sizes until they are naturally phased out and replaced by metric ones. Indexing facilities can be converted to permit metric readings. Inspectors must be equipped with sufficient metric measuring devices from the start.

results.title: Dimensional co-ordination
results.creator_credit: A.E.C. Hopkins and Helen Wiggins Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Keys to Metrication”.
A film for specialised audiences to demonstrate the advantages of metrication in the building and construction industry. Standardisation of dimensional units will mean less wastage of materials, and simplicity in planning and design.

results.title: Further extensions to the skill range
results.creator_credit: Don Kelly and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Judo”.
The object of the third film in this series is to show how the range can be enlarged still further while keeping to the same pattern of learning as the first two films. Training exercises, a strangle shown from the back of the opponent, more throws - Kouchi and Kosoto-gake, an introduction to sutemi-waza, and some free play are shown. Photographed by Don Kelly.

results.title: Extending the skill range
results.creator_credit: Don Kelly and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Judo”.
Demonstrates various judo movements including uchimata, osotagake and their avoidances; straight and bent armlocks; randori as part of training.

results.title: Further skills
results.creator_credit: Don Kelly and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Judo”.
The object of the fourth film is to “sound off” the basic skills of judo. In this demonstration harai-goshi and uchi-mata are contrasted and tsurikomi-goshi - a blocking type of throw, some immobilisations, throws, and ankle-trips are illustrated.

results.title: Counter attacks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Judo”.
Having learnt the many techniques and the various factors which influence the way these techniques are used, the next stop is to learn how they can be linked. There are two main linking techniques - defensive and offensively; defensive linkage is known as countering. Counter take several forms, the value of which will depend largely upon the attitude of the person using them. Specific counters demonstrated are osoto-gaeshi, uchi-mata-gaeshi, an ippon-seoi-counter, waki-gatame and speed counters.

results.title: Combination attacks
results.creator_credit: Don Kelly and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Judo”.
In judo, combination attacks are very important in the application of tactics, and in their turn tactics play a part in competition. Combination attacks have more objectives than simple terminal throwing. One other obvious objective is to tire the opponent. If attach after attack is launched and every time the opponent has to avoid and by doing so moves into another attack, it can becomes very exhausting - both physically and mentally. Here are demonstrated ouchi-gari into uchi-mata, ouchi-gari into tai-otoshi, ouchi-mata into sutemi-waza and ne-waza combination.
